description: From an aphetic form of Middle English acloyen, from Old French enclouer, encloer, from Vulgar Latin *inclāvāre, from Late Latin clāvāre, present active infinitive of clāvō, from Latin clāvus.

verbs.description: cloy (third-person singular simple present cloys, present participle cloying, simple past and past participle cloyed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fill up or choke up; to stop up.
(transitive) To clog, to glut, or satisfy, as the appetite; to satiate.
(transitive) To fill to loathing; to surfeit.
